description: From Middle English bound, bund (preterite) and bounden, bunden, ibunden, ȝebunden (past participle), from Old English bund- and bunden, ġebunden respectively. See bind.

entries.meaning: (with infinitive) Obliged (to).
examples: You are not legally bound to reply.

entries.meaning: (linguistics, of a morpheme) That cannot stand alone as a free word.
(mathematics, logic, of a variable) Constrained by a quantifier.
(dated) Constipated; costive.
Confined or restricted to a certain place; e.g. railbound.
Unable to move in certain conditions; e.g. snowbound.
simple past tense and past participle of bind
examples: I bound the splint to my leg.
I had bound the splint with duct tape.

description: From Middle English bownde, alternation (with -d partly for euphonic effect and partly by association with Etymology 1 above) of Middle English boun, from Old Norse búinn, past participle of búa (“to prepare”).

adjectives.description: bound (comparative more bound, superlative most bound)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Ready, prepared.
Ready to start or go (to); moving in the direction (of).
examples: Is that message bound for me?

entries.meaning: (with infinitive) Very likely (to), certain to
examples: They were bound to come into conflict eventually.

description: From Middle English bounde, from Old French bunne, from Medieval Latin bodina, earlier butina (“a bound, limit”).

entries.meaning: (often used in plural) A boundary, the border which one must cross in order to enter or leave a territory.
examples: I reached the northern bound of my property, took a deep breath and walked on.
Somewhere within these bounds you may find a buried treasure.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) A value which is known to be greater or smaller than a given set of values.

description: From Middle English bounden, from the noun (see above).

verbs.description: bound (third-person singular simple present bounds, present participle bounding, simple past and past participle bounded)

entries.meaning: To surround a territory or other geographical entity; to form the boundary of.
examples: France, Portugal, Gibraltar and Andorra bound Spain.
Kansas is bounded by Nebraska on the north, Missouri on the east, Oklahoma on the south and Colorado on the west.

entries.meaning: (transitive, mathematics) To be the bound of.

description: From Middle English *bounden (attested as bounten), from French bondir (“leap", "bound", originally "make a loud resounding noise”); perhaps from Late Latin bombitāre, present active infinitive of bombitō (“hum, buzz”), frequentative verb, from Latin bombus (“a humming or buzzing”).

entries.meaning: A sizeable jump, great leap.
examples: The deer crossed the stream in a single bound.

entries.meaning: A spring from one foot to the other in dancing.
(dated) A bounce; a rebound.

verbs.description: bound (third-person singular simple present bounds, present participle bounding, simple past and past participle bounded)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To leap, move by jumping.
examples: The rabbit bounded down the lane.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to leap.
(intransitive, dated) To rebound; to bounce.
examples: a rubber ball bounds on the floor

entries.meaning: (transitive, dated) To cause to rebound; to throw so that it will rebound; to bounce.
examples: to bound a ball on the floor
